Godot 3 - issue with project file on Windows
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Godot master 17 September 2017
Windows 10 
Don't know if other platforms are effected

**Issue description:**
Project file is loaded incompletely after export on windows, see errors pasted below:
```
ERROR: decode_variant: Condition ' (type & 0xFF) >= Variant::VARIANT_MAX ' is true. returned: ERR_INVALID_DATA
   At: core\io\marshalls.cpp:98
ERROR: decode_variant: Condition ' err ' is true. returned: err
   At: core\io\marshalls.cpp:542
ERROR: Error decoding property: input/move_left
   At: core\project_settings.cpp:471
ERROR: decode_variant: Condition ' len < 4 ' is true. returned: ERR_INVALID_DATA
   At: core\io\marshalls.cpp:93
ERROR: Error decoding property: ight4
   At: core\project_settings.cpp:471
ERROR: decode_variant: Condition ' len < 4 ' is true. returned: ERR_INVALID_DATA
   At: core\io\marshalls.cpp:93
ERROR: Error decoding property:
   At: core\project_settings.cpp:471
ERROR: decode_variant: Condition ' len < 4 ' is true. returned: ERR_INVALID_DATA
   At: core\io\marshalls.cpp:93
ERROR: Error decoding property:
   At: core\project_settings.cpp:471
```
Looks like there is some corruption in exporting the input map

**Steps to reproduce:**
Configure a project with input mapping, export to a pck file, run pck file, input mapping doesn't get setup

**Link to minimal example project:**

data.title: Fixed naming of pck file
data.body:
Oops, I broke this in my haste to fix things for OSX. On OSX the get_basename function was being overzealous as there is no dot in the executable name but there is in the bundle name, but there still is a dot in the executable name on Windows.

So it is now doing a get_filename first to get the full name of the executable without the path, then calling get_basename to strip off any extension if applicable.

I am still having issues on windows with it not wanting to open up the pck file. Not sure yet why but I don't think its due to the filename anymore.

data.title: Fix x11 exported executables not getting the +x flag
data.body:
This is a partial fix for #527.
When exporting for X11 on Linux or Mac the executable will get the 0755 mode flags. This doesn't affects when exporting for X11 on Windows.

data.title: Compile Godot with Clang 5.0 with the mingw32-64 and posix threading.
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Ubuntu Linux (Bash for Windows); Godot master; 

**Issue description:**
Allow the use of Clang 5.0 with the mingw32-64 ONLY WITH posix threading.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Now allows:

```
wget -O - http://apt.llvm.org/llvm-snapshot.gpg.key | sudo apt-key add -
Add the PPA:
sudo apt-add-repository "deb http://apt.llvm.org/xenial/ llvm-toolchain-xenial-5.0 main"
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install -y mingw-w64 build-essential cmake scons clang-5.0 # ccache distcc
# https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/9258
$ sudo update-alternatives --config x86_64-w64-mingw32-gcc
<choose x86_64-w64-mingw32-gcc-posix from the list>
$ sudo update-alternatives --config x86_64-w64-mingw32-g++
# HACK HACK HACK to force posix
sudo mv /usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-w64-mingw32/5.3-win32 ~
# END HACK HACK HACK
sudo update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/cc cc /usr/bin/clang-5.0 100
sudo update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/c++ c++ /usr/bin/clang-5.0 100
sudo update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/clang++ clang++ /usr/bin/clang-5.0 100
sudo update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/clang clang /usr/bin/clang-5.0 100
git clone https://github.com/tpoechtrager/wclang.git
cmake .
make
make install
git clone https://github.com/godotengine/godot.git
cd godot
scons p=windows bits=64 target=release_debug use_llvm=yes
```

```
diff --git a/platform/windows/detect.py b/platform/windows/detect.py
index 5bd9a78f4..ea154ee5b 100644
--- a/platform/windows/detect.py
+++ b/platform/windows/detect.py
@@ -249,6 +249,21 @@ def configure(env):
         env['AR'] = mingw_prefix + "ar"
         env['RANLIB'] = mingw_prefix + "ranlib"
         env['LD'] = mingw_prefix + "g++"
+
+        if (env["use_llvm"] == "yes"):
+            env["CC"] = mingw_prefix + "clang"
+            env['AS'] = mingw_prefix + "as"
+            env['CXX'] = mingw_prefix + "clang++"
+            env['AR'] = mingw_prefix + "ar"
+            env['RANLIB'] = mingw_prefix + "ranlib"
+            env['LD'] = mingw_prefix + "clang++"
+            # Allow linking to dlls in mingw32
+            env.Append(CPPFLAGS=['-Xclang', '-flto-visibility-public-std'])
+            env.Append(CPPFLAGS=['-pthread'])
+            # Hack to allow multiple definitions
+            env.Append(LINKFLAGS=['-Wl,--allow-multiple-definition'])
+            env.Append(LINKFLAGS=['-pthread'])
+
         env["x86_libtheora_opt_gcc"] = True

         ## Compile flags
```

Also depends on https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/11333.

Issue tracking wclang + posix threading https://github.com/tpoechtrager/wclang/issues/37

Issue tracking clang 4.0 support https://github.com/tpoechtrager/wclang/issues/31

Issue tracking static causes multiple symbols to be defined https://github.com/Alexpux/MINGW-packages/issues/1819

Issue tracking `Cannot compile with "-static" when using exceptions ` https://github.com/tpoechtrager/wclang/issues/32

data.title: Mouse right click on filesystem's panel (feature)
data.body:
This is more a suggestion than a real issue it would apply to any OS.
I am currently working with Godot 2.1.4.

Basically to add a faster and handier way to move around/create/rename files and directories directly from godot's FileSystem panel.
Right clicking on the background would give us option to create a new directory or file.
Right clicking of a directory/file would allow us to rename/delete/copy it.
etc...

An other benefit would be that creating directories, renaming and moving files outside of Godot does loose dependencies  but in Godot we might be able to do all that with additional look ups.

When working on a large project I often find myself wanting to sort my files differently or move things from growing directories to keep things dry for the eyes and organized.
These changes would allow large projects to be easily managed all from the Godot engine without having to open an explorer window, 3rd party editor or terminal aside.

data.title: Cannot load GDNative library
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Arch linux, godot 3.0 master branch

**Issue description:**
I am trying to get working GDNative library.
When I do `gdn.initialize()` I get an error:
Can't open dynamic library: [...]/libextensions.so. Error: [...]/libextensions.so: undefined symbol: _ZN5godot14_RegisterState19nativescript_handleE

I am afraid, that it can be problem on linux. Yesterday I was trying the same on Windows, and library was loaded. But I was getting error when try to call some methods. But it was yesterday's master, so I don't know if some changes in master branch could cause it. And I can't check it on windows right now.

I could try to find some solution if someone can give me a direction to search, because for this moment I don't know what can be wrong.

data.title: RigidBody in Character mode can disappear when changing angular velocity in script
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Windows 10 64bit - Godot 3.0 b9fddc5

**Issue description:**
The RigidBody in Character mode will disappear and these error messages will show up
![Error messages](https://i.imgur.com/cyCnKnK.png)

Here is the script that causes this issue:
```GDScript
extends RigidBody

func _ready():
	# Apply a small rotation force once
	angular_velocity = Vector3(0, 10, 0)

func _integrate_forces(state):
	var av = state.get_angular_velocity()
	av *= 0.5
	state.set_angular_velocity(av)
```

Specifically it's the `av *= 0.5` that's causing the problem. It only happens when av gets very very small but not exactly 0. Small enough that printing it shows it as 0.

**Link to minimal example project:**
[physics_glitch.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1308536/physics_glitch.zip)

data.title: Build errors related to spatial_editor_plugin.cpp

                                 ^~~~~~~~~~

Added Left / Right arrow navigation in tree, issue 10737
data.body:
Added Left / Right arrow navigation in tree.

Pressing left/right will collapse/expand the node, providing you are on the end column, if its already expanded/collapsed it will move up/down.

Pressing alt will collapse/expand the current and all its child nodes.

closes #10737

data.title: Drag and drop for meshes directly.
data.body: Adds support to the spatial editor to also add meshes directly via dragging and dropping them into the scene editor. Doing so will automatically create a MeshInstance with the mesh assigned. Also fixes the canvas editor so that only texture types will appear as valid objects to drop.

data.title: Discussion about the new default script editor font
data.body:
I was trying out the latest editor changes, when I noticed the new default script editor font, Mononoki (the screenshot was taken on Windows):

![Mononoki on Windows](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/180032/30511862-5ffc98a4-9ae2-11e7-96c8-4e1cd58b55e1.png)

*(Note: click on the images to display them in a new tab, at 1:1 size)*

It looks less readable to me, compared to the previous script editor font (Source Code Pro). I've found Hack to be a very nice programming font, so I may be biased, but I feel like it's still important to start a discussion on this – readability of the default fonts used in the editor is essential to a good user experience.

@djrm sent me this screenshot of the Mononoki font on Linux, it looks better, but it's still less readable than most of the fixed-width fonts I'm used to:

![Mononoki on Linux](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/180032/30511864-6002c8f0-9ae2-11e7-9864-be31931ca0ea.png)

He tried out the [Hack](https://sourcefoundry.org/hack/) font, and it looks much more readable. On this screenshot, it's a bit large, but its size could be lowered a bit and it still could be very readable:

![Hack on Linux](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/180032/30511915-490c4698-9ae3-11e7-9261-de3c6cd360ae.png)

(The license of Hack is a custom one, it's similar to the SIL OFL, but it still is [DFSG-compatible](https://packages.debian.org/sid/fonts-hack-ttf) so it should be good.)

Feel free to voice your opinion below :)
